fields.description:
In a Issue Tracker, I've created several issues with attachments with "exe", "png", "ppt" extensions. Once these issues have been Exported and Imported back into the repository the attachment which is being downloaded are downloaded with a different extension.

This issue can be reproduced with the steps below and as shown in the attached screenshot.

*Steps*

# Create Issue
# Attach a file with ".exe" extension
# Create 2nd Issue and attach a file with a ".png" extension
# Created 3rd Issue and attach a file with a ".ppt" extension
# Download all files with correct extension
# Export the Issues and the Import it back again (could be the same repository or a different\\
repository).
# Download the file for the latest Issues in the list , it downloads the file with the extension ".png".

*Screenshot*

!2672813608-1.PNG|thumbnail!

!333991132-2.PNG|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Attachments in Issue Tracker are downloading in different formats after exporting and importing

fields.description:
Would it be possible to add a new field next to each whitelisted IP so that we can note why that listing is needed and which user it belongs to? Our list is growing out of control and we have no idea how to prune it. The only way is to delete everything and then re-add users one by one  while tracking them in a different spreadsheet somewhere.

I only ask because it sounds like an quick thing to do.
fields.summary: Add notes or description to whitelisted IPs

fields.description: When new branches are pushed and you click on the "Branches" menu item in the BitBucket UI, the branches don't appear right away. You always have to do a manual page reload in the browser after clicking on the "Branches" menu item in order for the new branches to appear. This was not the case in the old UI and can get rather annoying, when you try to find a branch.
fields.summary: New branches only show after manual page reload

I did a push/commit in eclipse and it said it was successful. But, I looked online and nothing was changed. I changed the names of about a dozen files and the bitbucket repo doesn't show any change to their names.

:-(

-Ted
fields.summary: Name change not updated in repo

fields.summary: "Requires issue key in commit message" prevents default UI commits

fields.summary: Ukrainian translation don't have reviewers on transifex

Would it be possible to show the Git URL on Overview also to empty repos? Once customer needs to use a totally empty repo it does not exhibit the URL.

!3012010092-Screen%20Shot%202017-10-27%20at%2018.23.39.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Empty repos don't show git url on overview page

fields.description: Upon switching from a free -> standard or free -> premium plan, there appears to be a delay sync in switching over to the new plan. This will prevent the customer from using newly added Pipelines minutes or Git-LFS space right away
fields.summary: Delay in billing plan synchronization

fields.description:
Issue BCLOUD-14080 was opened back in April about the changes that were logging people out of Bitbucket frequently.  It was marked resolved, but it continues to be a major problem for many of us who use Bitbucket regularly, but not daily.  Comments from staff in May indicated they would continue looking at this, but it hasn't been updated in over 5 months.  This is a major nuisance impacting several people on our team, and I'm getting requests from my team members to start looking at other platforms.

Having a 3 day session expiration does not seem consistent with industry expectations.  I'm not aware of any similar platform that is as restrictive as Bitbucket, and Atlassian has not provided any explanation of why this is a necessary restriction.
fields.summary: Getting logged out frequently

fields.description:
https://bitbucket.org/account/user/<username>/features/

Or Settings > Integrations and Features > Labs

Under "Atlassian Editor" it says "...automatically concerts most Markdown..."

"concerts" should be "converts"
fields.summary: Typo on the "Labs" page

fields.description:
h1. PICTURES AND ATTACHMENTS ENHANCEMENTS
Developers attach images to PR's to show before and after code changes to UI issues to help reviewers see what the change is doing on the glass. Unfortunately, some pictures are large which forces a lot of scrolling especially if these pictures are in comments in code lines.

* Add support for image size adjustment similar to Confluence
* Allow devs and reviewers to attach pictures and adjust their size to show only thumbnail size and click to expand.
* All these attachments to also just be links
* Implement anchor link tagging to images so that users can attach pictures or thumbnails in the main comments section that link to code comments or files in the Pull Request
fields.summary: As a developer I would like to have minimized pictures in PR's

fields.description: Currently the most recent commit is shown first.  Which is great, but otherwise the list is shown in lexicographic (I assume) order.  I'd prefer most recently updated as my target branch would almost always be in the top two or three hits.  This is especially useful for those of us that merge to a review branch/environment before a PR is generated.  Therefore the target branch is almost never the actual most recent branch.
fields.summary: Order the pull request branch drop down by most recently committed

fields.description:
See your example link  :https://bitbucket.org/tutorials/markdowndemo/overview  It shows nothing more than a non readable text.\\
In comments inside issues it doesn't work neither, although it works well on the overview of my repo.
fields.summary: Mardown doesn't work in comments

fields.description: Provide the ability to disable or hide the _Approve_ button in PR until all tasks are completed.
fields.summary: Disable Approve button until all PR tasks completed

fields.description:
Discrepancy in behavior UI vs API for team accounts with "Private Profile".

When you have a team account - in the UI only the Admin of the team account can Administer the team and add/remove and manage members who have access to the team account and repos.

Only Admin of the team account can VIEW the users on the team.

However when you run a GET request over API, example:

https://api.bitbucket.org/2.0/teams/(TeamAccountName)/members?page=1

Any user running this request will get the list of users and their Display name via this request without being a member of the team or the team Admin.

Issue: non-team members shouldn't be able to get a list of users over API if it's not available to them in the UI.
fields.summary: API GET call for team members with "Private Profile" returns the list of members, even when made by non-member

fields.description:
Suggestion:  to bring the clone URL for brand new repos right in the\\
overview page instead of hiding it under "Get started with command line"\\
to make it more user friendly
fields.summary: When the repo is brand new, it's not very intuitive where to find a Clone URL

fields.description: When trying to add a team member to a branch permission we are getting an error.
fields.summary: Branch permissions not updating

fields.description:
When reviewing a pull request's diff, if one file is changed extensively, I often have to scroll through quite a few lines while reviewing the changes to that file. Sometimes I forget what file I'm looking at by the time I get to the end, and I have to scroll back up to the top of the file to see the header indicating the file path. This precision scroll jump can be difficult if there are lots of files in the diff; if you go too quickly, you can miss the separation padding between files. Then I have to jump back down to the next file to continue reviewing.

I suggest floating the file header with the file path so that it is always visible, or "sticky" to the top of the screen. When you begin scrolling through a diff, eventually the diff of first file listed will begin to move offscreen. When this happens, the filename header should remain onscreen by sliding down from its original position. Only when the file diff is completely scrolled offscreen should the filename also scroll offscreen.
fields.summary: Use sticky/floating header to indicate filename when scrolling large diff in PR/commit

fields.description:
Pull request descriptions and comments often include screenshots, capturing modified UI, bugs, etc. When developing mobile applications for iOS devices with retina screens, these images can become quite large (in the neighborhood of at least 1,500-2,000 px each dimension). Currently, all images are shown inline and at original size. This makes it very difficult and unpleasant to scroll through and read a pull request once any images have been added.

I suggest reducing all images to thumbnails (~100-150 px each dimension), and showing those inline, with links that open the originally-sized images in a popover view.
fields.summary: Thumbnail all images in pull request description and comments

fields.description:
Imagine you have a PR with several files changed in it.

During review, you make the comments about the changes that will cause you to decline the PR.

The developer fixes the issues and then resubmits a new PR.

You now have to go and examine all the files that are unchanged between the two PRs all over again. It may not be the same reviewer.

It would be REALLY useful to be able to mark files/diff chunks as reviewed, and, if the chunks remain the same between reviews, they are collapsed in some way.

The constant scrolling up and down looking at things which we have no way of ignoring once we've reviewed them, makes it just a little painful to do.
fields.summary: Ability to mark elements of a pull request as OK.

fields.description:
It will be best that Bitbucket Cloud also includes Rebase workflow.

https://www.atlassian.com/blog/bitbucket/bitbucket-server-5-5-personal-tokens-rebase
fields.summary: Rebase Workflow

fields.description: The list of regions is not sorted alphabetically. This makes it hard to find US East 2, for example.
fields.summary: Sort CodeDeploy region dropdown alphabetically
Golang - go get over ssh

fields.description:
When a branch (develop) is created from its source branch (master), it will automatically trigger a build for the commit on the develop branch. A build has already been triggered for this commit on the master branch previously.

With a build being triggered upon creation of a new branch, it would be running the same commit for the second time. This uses up the build minutes for a build that has already completed.

It would be better if a pipelines build is not triggered upon creation of a new branch.
fields.summary: Don't trigger pipelines build when a branch is created

fields.description:
Repos can be either git or hg, but the only indication regular users have that a given repo is one or the other is the SSH URL on the overview page. Since the git and hg commands are not interchangeable, there are a lot of users who try to {{git clone}} an hg repo; that fails with a 404 status on HTTPS or "not a git repository" on SSH.

Please add an icon to the overview page or somewhere that shows whether a given repository uses git or hg.
fields.summary: Indicate on the overview page whether the repo is git or hg

the link is broken

Workaround, here is the proper link until the issue is resolved:\\
https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/authy/id494168017?mt=8
fields.summary: Broken link to Authy for iOS

fields.description:
Projects are really useful for group repositories, but using teams to own them is rigid.

I do research and typically a few people, possibly from different institutions, will come together to do a single project together. I could make a team for every research project, then create a project for that project, but this seems like a really silly workflow. I'd like to be able to create a project where I, and anyone else I assign, is the owner, without having to create a team. I could then add users with different roles to the project as needed. This seems much more flexible than the current workflow.

Does this already exist somehow?
fields.summary: Projects for Users, not Teams

fields.description: Currently, the Bitbucket Cloud web UI only offer to the customers the ability to filter the Active or the merged one. There are some customers that are requesting the ability to view "all" the branches.
fields.summary: Show all branches

fields.description:
See BCLOUD-13800 for some original context and discussion. It might be desirable to automatically remove users from all of the branch permissions on all of the repositories owned by a team when removing them from the team.

One [counterargument|BCLOUD-13800] to doing this is that if a user is removed from a team _accidentally_, then after adding them back it will be necessary to manually restore all branch restrictions to the way they were, which could be tedious.

Note that the current behavior does not represent a bug in authorization. Users still cannot access repositories if they do not have read privileges through either group membership or direct access, even if they are included in branch permissions on those repositories.
fields.summary: Removing a user's repo access should remove them from all relevant branch permissions

Only one of these messages should appear, though they both go to the same places and work the same.

Can't push anymore !!!

fields.description:
With the current Pipelines base image(atlassian/default-image), users received the error below while performing "curl https://www.google.com":

{code}
#!python

# curl https://www.google.com
curl: (60) SSL certificate problem: unable to get local issuer certificate
More details here: http://curl.haxx.se/docs/sslcerts.html

curl performs SSL certificate verification by default, using a "bundle"
 of Certificate Authority (CA) public keys (CA certs). If the default
 bundle file isn't adequate, you can specify an alternate file
 using the --cacert option.
If this HTTPS server uses a certificate signed by a CA represented in
 the bundle, the certificate verification probably failed due to a
 problem with the certificate (it might be expired, or the name might
 not match the domain name in the URL).
If you'd like to turn off curl's verification of the certificate, use
 the -k (or --insecure) option.
{code}

Once the base image is updated using the commands - "apt-get update && apt-get upgrade -y", user able to perform the curl command without the error.
fields.summary: Pipelines: Request to update atlassian/default-image

fields.description:
At the moment you can allow Bitbucket Pipelines to make modifications to a repository by adding an SSH key inside Bitbucket Pipelines configuration and then adding the corresponding public key to the team access keys. The latter grants read-write access to every repository.

Could you add a simple checkbox to Bitbucket Pipelines to enable read-write access to the same repository? Upon enabling the access Bitbucket Pipelines should be allowed to push changes to the repository (assuming the image has git installed).

This enhancement would simplify configuration quite a bit.
fields.summary: Allow Bitbucket Pipelines read-write access to the repository

fields.description:
How to reproduce:
# Create over 10 repos with on a given BB account with the following pattern:
    test-test1
    test-test1
    ...
    test-test12
    test
# Create a new Board on Trello -> Powerups > Bitbucket Cloud --> Enable
# Click on Bitbucket Power-up -> Add Repo -> type in "test"

Notice that only repos from "test-test1 " through "test-test10" will show up, you will not be able to find the repo "test" to connect it at all,  and the only way to find the next sub-set or repo is type in the "test-test1".

More user friendly version would be to have a scroll bar to view all available repos that start with "test".

The only workaround is to connect the Board from Bitbucket Side from the repo.
From Trello Powerups the "test" repo will never show up to select it.
fields.summary: Bitbucket Trello Powerup - doesn't list all repos when trying to connect the board

fields.description:
I'm over quality for a server team that provides functionality for a web client, Android app and iOS app. The backend team recently started working on moving to a Microservices architecture. As a division, we use JIRA for Kanban in an effort to move towards being able to continuously deliver. This means that we have numerous repositories with completely different concerns when it comes to code review and merging pull requests.

Because of this, I have been looking for a good way to integrate a checklist into our process that prevents code from merging into master unless it's ready. It would be a game changer if each repo admin could set up a custom checklist template that had to be completed before being able to merge. There are a handful of plugins that let you automate blocking merges for a specific condition, but not everything a team wants to require is already built into software somewhere.

Examples include necessary unit testing, integration testing, end to end API and/or UI testing, feature functionality, build success, deployment success, code formatting checks, etc. With the multitude of automation integrations available with Atlassian products, this and some API endpoints would allow teams to completely automate code review instead of needing different tools for every check.

If this feature was to get added, a major subsequent feature would be to enable or disable nested checklists from repo admin perspective as well. This would allow devs and QA to add/edit/delete checklists that implicitly become required before a merge as well.
fields.summary: Repository level checklists for merging

We have a strict policy that the PR must be approved by its authors before the code review process. I would like to have an indication/icon in the PR list if the PR is approved be the author. You can add another column, to the view, or tou can simply add the same green icon to the authors photo/avatar as you do with the code reviewers.

fields.description:
*Better search capability in 'Pull requests'*

Typing an issue # in the 'Search' text box in the upper right corner of the web page sometimes works and sometimes doesn't. Apparently, all the pull requests in the current "view" (Open, Merged or Declined) have to first be loaded up to ensure that the Search always works the first time. To load up all the requests, I have to either scroll and/or page all the way down the current view/web page (ensuring that all requests have been loaded up).

We should not be required to either scroll and/or page all the way down the current view/web page to get the Search to work the first time; that's the enhancement request.
fields.summary: Better search capability in 'Pull requests'

#!python

remote: ********************************************************************************
remote: [ALERT] Your push failed because the account 'ronctest' has exceeded its
remote: [ALERT] user limit and this repository is restricted to read-only access.
remote: [ALERT] Contact the account admin to upgrade their plan to restore write access.

{code}

fields.summary: Impossible transfer repo to another account
Pipelines: SSH KeyScan fails on creating certain Known Hosts. (BP-847)

fields.description:
Bitbucket pipeline is often failing because of a "System error" saying "Error occurred whilst uploading artifact":

!543547393-Capture%20d%E2%80%99%C3%A9cran%202017-10-20%20%C3%A0%2010.59.31.png|thumbnail!

Here is the bitbucket-pipeline section of the step where the System error occurred:

{code}
- step:
      name: Generate APIBlueprint documentation
      image:
        name: <custom docker image hosted on aws ecr>
        aws:
          access-key: $AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID
          secret-key: $AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY
      script:
        - <generate documentation.apib file>
        - cp documentation.apib dist/documentation.apib
      artifacts:
        - dist/documentation.apib
{code}

Re-running the pipeline usually solves the problem, letting me think it's not an issue in our bitbucket-pipeline.yml file.
fields.summary: Pipelines randomly fail with: "Error occurred whilst uploading artifact". (BP-1174)

fields.description:
My team is on "Free with overages" plan, as soon as we went over 50 free minutes of Pipelines, the "You're now paying for additional build minutes..." notification is displayed nearly every time which is overly annoying (I tried clicking both 'See your plan details' and 'Learn more' but seems like there is no 'Ok, I got it' behavior).

I suppose once you have billed those additional minutes, it does not make sense to warn users every time (except when you are about to run out of your paid minutes)
fields.summary: BBS-256 "You're now paying for additional build minutes" notification is displayed constantly

fields.description: When I try to add a new member who doesn't have a Bitbucket account to a team, they are not automatically added to the team after they have created their account. In order for them to appear in my team I need to re-add them after they've created their account. Once this is done the outstanding invite still shows, even though they've already been added as a member of the team.
fields.summary: Inviting a user to a team doesn't automatically add them to the team (BBCDEV-8201)
Make Windows code fonts more legible.

fields.description:
When commenting on a pull request on bitbucket.org, I've found that if you create a task by highlighting a code comment you have made and pressing the {{Create task}} link, the controls for editing or deleting that task to not appear.

This issue is unique to creating via copy - it works fine when creating without highlighting first, and copying the text into place.  Upon page reload, the links appear, but they do not initially exist.  This may seem trivial, but it can be frustrating to deal with if the PR is large.

Steps to reproduce:

* In an existing pull request:
* create a comment anywhere in a changed code section.
* highlight the comment.
* Press {{Create task}}.  A new task will be created without Edit or delete links.
* Clear the text selection, and press {{Create task}} again.  A new task will be generated that _does_ have the aforementioned links.
fields.summary: Edit / Delete task links not present when task is copied into existence.

fields.description:
For large or complex projects, BitBucket makes it very hard to organize issues with enough granularity.  This can be greatly improved by:

# Keeping Issue number as a separate field (not adding a number to the front of  an issue name)
# Adding custom fields user can use to break down the issue area (see below)

!1997236647-BitBucket_Support_Improvement_Issue.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Issue Tracker - Add Fields - Parse Fields

fields.description:
At the moment it seems that the clone level can be configured only as a global settings.

For us it would be really useful to be able to specify a different clone level for certain steps which modify the git repository. It's a waste of resources to enable it globally only if a single steps needs the whole repository.

Would it be possible to add the option to override the global clone level for a specific step?
fields.summary: Allow configuring the clone level at the step level

fields.description:
Seems only happening with WIKI page for account with a lot of issues.

Create a WIKI page,  mention " Issue # ", save a wiki page, the Link for the Issue should be active. Edit the page again and add more Issues to the page, save - the issue links become inactive and just show up as text.\\
The behavior is not consistent and seem to be happening with FireFox and Google Chrome.\\
The workaround is to Edit the WIKI page, delete one of the issues and type it in again, re-save the page and the Issue links become active again...
fields.summary: When modifying wiki page, randomly Issue links become inactive

fields.description:
Currently the repository pages are always public, which doesn't really make sense.

In our project for example, we'd like to generate a JavaDoc for the documentation, this however, always is HTML output and thus cannot be used on the Wiki.

Since the project is private, we cannot put it on the pages right now either as the whole world who know the url would be able to view the documentation.

It would make sense to be able to configure pages to be private, where the server would first check if the person who is trying to view the page is logged in, and if so, if he has the permissions to view the repository. This shouldn't be that hard to implement either as you could just create a wrapper for this, or use http headers for (token-based) authentication. (Just throwing some ideas)
fields.summary: Add a private option for repository pages

fields.description:
Hello all,

Everyone could access to the page of members of our project without any account or rights on it. We try to do it on our side and I confirm we can  do the same on several others projects, unknown of us......\\
If Sam Gabal is reading it, I can access his page ;  the same for Benjamin Ghenne, Jérémy Huet, Lucie Harive, .... and many others -> A kind of security flaw, don't U think so ?

...don't know who declare as assignee....
fields.summary: Viewing members of project without any bitbucket account.....

fields.description:
I was trying to clone a repo within a project in my org. Went to the UI to get the automatic remote URL

The UI provided:\\
<username>@bitbucket.org:<org>/<repo>\\
It should be\\
<username>@bitbucket.org**/**<org>/<repo>

If you need specific repo information, plenty of people on the dev team know how to reach me.
fields.summary: SSH remote path incorrect

fields.description: On Bitbucket Online, when on the page for a specific commit - I want to trigger a pipeline build  and I find the link fast and click it while the page is still rendering because there it is in plain sight. But the page jumps and causes me to click the wrong link...arrrghhhh!
fields.summary: Commit Page Jumps Causing Wrong Link Click

fields.description: There is currently no feedback that a user has been added to a group.  This can lead to accidental users membership to private repository.  The add to group should at least have another step to say are you sure or a email notification to admins of the team when a user is added.

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
When creating a branch permission, the option *Check for 1 successful build on the last commit* automatically enforces that there are *no* failed builds on the last commit.

This is not very clear to the end users, there is some text in the dialog mentioning "Also notifies users of failed builds before merging". However, it's not very clear that this option prevents merging in case of a failed build.

In cases where users have 1 successful and 1 failed build on the last commit, the merge fails when this option is enabled and it's not clear why.

h3. Suggested Solution
Change the text in the 'Branch permission' dialog, to make it clear that the option *Check for 1 successful build on the last commit* enforces _no_ failed builds on the last commit.
fields.summary: Mention in the branch permission dialog that the option "Check for 1 successful build on the last commit" also enforces no failed builds on last commit

fields.description:
Currently, Bitbucket supports IP Whitelisting for all the repositories hosted under the configured team account.

Bitbucket could provide an additional option to restrict IP addresses in the repository settings to provide repository specific whitelist.
fields.summary: Repository Specific IP Whitelisting

fields.description: On the "create repository" screen there is an option to create a new project at the same time. As there is no project privacy setting, it should follow the project's privacy setting. This is a problem when creating private repositories, as the projects created will be public.
fields.summary: New projects should not be public when creating private repository
